title: The ties that diffuse? Scrutinising the role of dyadic linkages in cross-national environmental spillovers
abstractText:
Is globalisation good for the environment? One possible way in which globalization might contribute to sustainability at the domestic level is by facilitating the diffusion of more environmentally-sound technologies, organisational practices and performances from more environmentally-progressive countries to less environmentally-progressive ones.

The over-arching aim of this research project is to examine the extent to which different forms of interconnection between countries contribute to such positive cross-national environmental spillovers. The project makes use of statistical techniques - known as spatial econometrics - which allow researchers to determine whether characteristics in one country "spillover" (that is, diffuse) to others via international contact. Two broad sets of environmental spillover are examined by the project:

  • environmental innovations such as environmentally-sound technologies, private environmental codes and environmental regulations;
  • actual levels of environmental performance such as carbon-intensity.

In order to provide a more sophisticated understanding of the role of globalisation, five different international linkages are investigated: trade, investment, telecommunications, diaspora and travel. Data for all five forms of linkage will be dyadic in nature, allowing the researchers to undertake a more geographically disaggregated analysis of the influence of international interconnections.
